Name: Staph aureus
Symptoms: skin abscess cellulitis pneumonia food poisoning *secretory diarrhea (watery, large volume) CNS infections endocarditis vascular infections septic arthritis osteomyelitis
serology: +catalase +gram +coagulase  may have beta-lactamases
virulence factors: biofilm 6 surface proteins Protein A - inhibits complement encapsulated
toxins: 5 cytotoxins 12 hemolytic enzymes  food poisoning  scalded skin syndrome
immune phenomena: toxic shock syndrome pus-forming abscess septic arthritis
epi. / notes: hospitalized people nosocomial recent flu  foods = salads, pastries, foods made by hand contact

Name: Staph epidermidis
Symptoms: CNS infections post-op complications device infections
serology: +catalase +gram -coagulase
virulence factors: biofilm colonizes polymer surfaces

Name: Staph saprophyticus
Symptoms: UTIs
serology: +catalase +gram -coagulase

Name: Strep pyogenes, GAS
Symptoms: pharyngitis strep throat cellulitis - skin impetigo - "crusting" scarlet fever necrotizing fasciitis
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase Group A b-hemolysis
virulence factors: M protein - antiphagocytic
toxins: Streptolysin O - exotoxin SpeA, SpeB, SpeC - superantigens
immune phenomena: acute rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis, strep toxic shock
epi. / notes: age 6-20 (a for adolescents) rare over 30 relapses after GAS pharyngitis ARF: cardiac disease worldwide

Name: Strep GBS
Symptoms: vomiting irritability
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase Group B b-hemolysis -bacitracin
epi. / notes: babies

Name: Strep pneumoniae (has vaccine)
Symptoms: pneumonia - acute productive cough, sputum pleuritic chest pain ear infection sinus infection meningitis (MOPS)
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase a-hemolytic aerobic +quellung +optochin
virulence factors: encapsulated no lancefield antigen  Resistance to b-lactams from altered transpeptidase PBPs
toxins: pneumolysin (TNF, IL-1 agonist) - kill cells  IgA protease - stay in resp. tract
epi. / notes: overcrowding smoking age <2, >60 day care no spleen

Name: Strep agalactiae
Symptoms: neo-natal sepsis maternal sepsis soft-tissue infection cellulitis
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase Group B b-hemolysis
epi. / notes: group B for babies

Name: Strep viridans
Symptoms: dental cavities endocarditis - S. mutans
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase a-hemolysis -optochin
epi. / notes: recent dental visit

Name: Strep sapro
Symptoms: UTIs
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase a-hemolysis +quellung (swelling)

Name: Enterococcus
Symptoms: UTIs biliary tract infection peritonitis endocarditis bacteremia intrabdominal infections
serology: +gram -catalase -coagulase group D nongroup D y-hemolysis'
epi. / notes: nosocomial infections in debilitated patients  appears while on broad spectrum antibiotics

Name: B. cereus
Symptoms: food poisoning (rice leftovers) 30 min-15 h incubation time  secretory diarrhea
serology: +gram
toxins: enterotoxin released into the food (secretory diarrhea)
epi. / notes: usually rice leftovers

Name: Listeria monocytogenes
Symptoms: Meningitis Foodborne illnesses
serology: +gram tumbling, end over end motility B hemolysis
virulence factors: Recruits host cell actin intracellularly
epi. / notes: infants, elderly immunocompromized  worry in pregnant women

Name: C. difficile
Symptoms: antibiotic-associated diarrhea pseudomembranous colitis bloody diarrhea food poisoning
serology: +gram anerobic spore forming!  EIA toxin assay (Cdiff toxin assay) PCR test Stool test
virulence factors: doesn't enter cells, destroys with toxins
toxins: Enterotoxin *inflam. diarr. Cytotoxin * sec. diarr.  A-B toxin pattern
mode of transmission: spores - air and relapses  direct contact
immune phenomena: septic shock toxic megacolon  may require bowel resection or death
epi. / notes: nosocomial, elderly need to wash hands after exposure!! no sanitizer kills spores!  fecal transplant helps eliminate this

Name: C. perfringens
Symptoms: gas gangene (fatal) soft-tissue infection cellulitis fasciitis diverticulitis contaminated wounds food poisoning secretory diarrhea (watery, large volume)
serology: +gram India ink prep - capsule hemolysis anerobic
toxins: toxic gas alpha toxin - partial hemolysis theta toxin - complete hemolysis
epi. / notes: nosocomial from wounds  uncooked beef, poultry, gravies

Name: C. tetani
Symptoms: tetanus lockjaw, sardonic grin spastic paralysis
serology: +gram anerobic spore forming!

Name: C. botulinum
Symptoms: botulism flaccid paralysis food poisoning
serology: +gram anerobic
epi. / notes: babies can get this

Name: Actinomyces
Symptoms: infections of the mouth "space infections" IUDs
serology: +gram anerobe growth only  sulfur granules pushed through skin - actual colonies of organism

Name: Nocardia
Symptoms: diarrhea abscesses lungs -> brain progression
serology: +gram aerobe and anerobic growth modified acid fast stain (different pH) hydrophobic, dry colonies
epi. / notes: immunocompromized esp. organ transplants

Name: diphtheriae
Symptoms: diptheria airway constriction cardiac, brain effects
serology: +gram tough paryngeal membrane

Name: Pseudomonas aeruginosa  rel: Burkholderia cepacia  rel: Stenotrophomas maltophila
Symptoms: hosp. acquired pneumo hosp. skin, soft tissue inf. sepsis, bacteremia endocarditis, ear infections eye infections "hot tub" folliculitis *complicated UTI (indwelling catheters) -diarrhea
serology: -gram -lactose +oxidase +catalase GREEN PIGMENT on gram stain aerobic
virulence factors: adherence LPS, protease siderophores flagella, pili motile
toxins: exotoxins: ExoS, ExoT, ExoU, ExoY  Pyocyanin pigment
epi. / notes: hospitalized patients ("nosocomial")  cystic fibrosis - mucoid immunocompromized burns diabetics IV drug abusers

Name: Klebsiella pneumoniae  [can be multidrug resistant (*all* b-lactam resistant)]
Symptoms: pneumonia w/RED sputum UTI intraabdominal infection liver abscess peritonitis wound infections/hosp. fever/chills
serology: -gram +lactose fermenter (MacConkey agar) +citrate -indol encapsulated  very viscous (mucoid)
virulence factors: encapsulated LPS siderophore pili
antibiotics: lots of resistance -ampicillin +Piperacillin-tazobactam +cefepime -fluoroquinoline +carbapenems last resort. +imipenem +tygacycline +gentamicin +polymyxin   source control - clean and remove
epi. / notes: alcoholics - aspirate gastric contents  most often - hospitalization recent wounds  immunocompromized diabetics  a superbug

Name: Legionella pneumophila
Symptoms: fever, malaise pneumonia slow onset, little sputum very dangerous +extrapulmonary effects like GI symptoms
serology: -gram need special media obligate aerobe dx: urine antigen sero 1, culture
virulence factors: pili, flagellae macrophage infectivity promoter
epi. / notes: unclean water sanitation/HVAC systems/cooling towers elderly/HIV

Name: Haemophilus influenzae
Symptoms: Meningitis Pneumonia Ear infection Sinus infection
serology: -gram ^Typeable A-D including hib ^Nontypeable (no capsule, less virulent) ^chocolate agar ^need Factor V / Factor X ^satellite colonies on blood agar -oxidase
virulence factors: encapsulated are higher risk
epi. / notes: Infants, Elderly, COPD  non vaccinated for Hib

Name: Moraxella catarrhalis
Symptoms: ear infection sinus infection pneumonia
serology: -gram +catalase aerobic
epi. / notes: COPD/emphysema

Name: Bordetella pertussis
Symptoms: Whooping cough (initial flu 1 wk. bursts of coughing 2wks.)
serology: -gram
epi. / notes: people without TdaP infants especially, COPD can occur in anyone

Name: Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcus)
Symptoms: Meningitis severe headache neck stiffness non-blanching rash rapid onset confusion (rare: some other areas)
serology: -gram +maltose +catalase +oxidase encapsulated (typeable) +Thayer-Martin media +quellung
virulence factors: encapsulated - resistance IgA protease - survival Pili - attachment Opa and Opc proteins
epi. / notes: 6 months-2 years age overcrowding college campuses splenectomy late complement deficiencies  meningitis belt in Africa Hajj in Mecca

Name: Neisseria gonorrhea
Symptoms: gonorrhea urethritis, cervicitis dysuria, purulent Meningitis Pharyngitis Conjunctivitis mostly asymptomatic occasionally can get into blood stream septic arthritis (low %)
serology: -gram -maltose +lactose +catalase +oxidase -quellung (no capsule) +Thayer-Martin media  nucleic acid amp test - most sensitive
virulence factors: pili
epi. / notes: sexual transmission men and women 15-24  cultures important in sexual abuse cases  30-70% coinfected with chlamydia

Name: Chlamydia trachomatis
Symptoms: mostly asymptomatic urethritis, cervicitis CLEAR discharge reactive arthritis (NOT septic) abortions, prematurity serovars L1-3: lymphadenitis
shape: cocci singlets not spore forming non-motile
serology: HARD TO GROW -gram nucleic acid amplification tests (vaginal swabs / first catch urine) serovars L1-3: lymphadenitis
immune phenomena: reactive arthritis in certain HLA subtypes

Name: E. coli
Symptoms: diarrhea UTI* most common cause lower and upper UTI hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) renal failure thrombocytopenia edema, pallor bloody diarrheaneo-natal sepsis  inflammatory diarrhea (bloody, small volume, WBC) = EHEC and EIEC  secretory diarrhea = ETEC
serology: -gram +lactose (MacConkey agar) -citrate +catalase +indol  can serotype on O, H, K Shigatoxin = stool, PCR EHEC sorbitol agar - O157:H7
virulence factors: disruption of host barriers O antigen = LPS H antigen = Flagella K antigen = capsule P - pili = most important virulence factor in UTI  attachment - EPEC biofilm - EAEC
toxins: LPS Pili - attachment to epithelial cells  AB exotoxin heat labile ST exotoxin heat stable  Shiga toxin - EHEC
antibiotics: +azithromycin +ciprofloxacin +ceftriaxone +cefotaxime  lower UTI: +Tri-Sulf  supportive treatment for EHEC - no antibio
mode of transmission: food/water - toxins ETEC  fecal/oral - pathogenic EPEC  direct/uncooked - EHEC
epi. / notes: recent travel - watery diarrhea - ETEC fecal/oral - diarrhea, localized in gut - EPEC bloody diarrhea = EHEC renal failure thrombocytopenia edema, pallor atyp. pneumo - ventilators use carbapenems  nosocomial = usually MDR

Name: Salmonella enteritidis (nontyphi)
Symptoms: inflammatory diarrhea (bloody, small volume, WBC) - nontyphi abdominal pain
serology: -gram -lactose motile bacteria +catalase -oxidase -urease +H2S test (HE plate)  dx: stool culture
virulence factors: invade M cells replicates inside phagocytic vacuole
epi. / notes: may look like typhoid in immunocompromized people  stays localized to intestine

Name: Salmonella typhi
Symptoms: Typhoid fever +typhi (small volume, bacteremia)  initial diarrhea  a SYSTEMIC illness long incubation period fever, rash (rose spots), abdominal pain -diarrhea (not often!)
serology: -gram -lactose motile bacteria +H2S test (HE plate) **ONLY serogroup D** dx: blood culture
virulence factors: nontyphoid + cross into intestinal submucosa disseminate around the body
mode of transmission: humans only reservoir  hides in gallbladder
epi. / notes: not endemic in US  vaccines available

Name: Shigella
Symptoms: inflammatory diarrhea (bloody, small volume, WBC)  seizures, altered mental status  invades epithelium
serology: -gram -lactose non-motile bacteria -H2S test (HE plate)  Stool smear --> white cells dx: stool culture
virulence factors: attach to M cells escapes phagosome uses host cell actin to spread (very much like listeria does) tumbling, end over end motility (like listeria)
mode of transmission: direct contact only (fecal/oral route)  very easy to transfer person to person
immune phenomena: Reiter syndrome: reactive arthritis urethritis conjunctivitis (pink eye)
epi. / notes: daycare centers MSM 1.1 million deaths/year  low infectious dose - ACID STABLE - can survive stomach and make you very sick

Name: Vibrio cholerae
Symptoms: abdominal pain low BP secretory diarrhea (watery, large volume)
serology: -gram -lactose +oxidase -catalase
virulence factors: flagella, pili
toxins: toxin which activates CFTR, blocks absorption of NaCl  AB toxin
epi. / notes: 3 million cases, 100k deaths per year mostly south asia, subsaharan Africa

Name: Proteus mirabilis
Symptoms: UTIs
serology: -gram +urease
epi. / notes: hospitalization

Name: Campylobacter jejuni
Symptoms: inflammatory diarrhea (bloody, small volume, WBC)
Sites: birds, other animals  uncooked meat/poultry  feces
serology: -gram culture at warm temp +oxidase +catalase dx: stool culture
immune phenomena: reactive arthritis  Guillain-Barre syndrome (paralysis going up body) - antibodies opsonize peripheral nerves via crossreaction
epi. / notes: one of the most common foodborne infections

Name: H. pylori
Symptoms: gastritis ulcers gastric cancer gastric MALT lymphomas
serology: -gram +urease = neutralizes gastric pH dx: urea based breath testing, stool antigen test
virulence factors: urease - allows it to survive in stomach
epi. / notes: treatment prevents gastric cancer

Name: Bacterioides fragilis
Symptoms: liver abscess "space infections"
serology: -gram anerobe +catalase +oxidase polysaccharide capsule

Name: Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
Symptoms: pneumonia
serology: -gram -lactose +catalase -oxidase
epi. / notes: ventilators cystic fibrosis

Name: Candida albicans (a fungi)
Symptoms: UTIs recent surgery infections of the bowel immunocompromized when on lots of antibiotics Candidiasis of skin and nails Oral thrush
serology: NULL gram (turns black)
epi. / notes: infection when the relative proportion of this organism among the microbiota is increased or there is a loss of neutrophil or T cell immunity a problem in debilitated patients patients being treated with antibiotics indwelling catheters.

Name: Yersinia
Symptoms: food poisoning inflammatory diarrhea, prolonged fever abdominal pain
mode of transmission: various animals contaminated milk, meat, water
immune phenomena: reactive arthritis in certain HLA types

Name: Mycoplasma pneumoniae
Symptoms: pneumonia chronic onset little to no fever +extrapulmonary manifestations
serology: resistant to gram stain use Giemsa stain Eaton media non acid fast  dx: antibody tests
epi. / notes: adolescents to young adults (school age)  sickle cell disease

Name: Mycobacteria tuberculosis
Symptoms: pneumonia upper respiratory infections hepatitis, anemia many extrapulmonary complications  chronic night sweats weight loss bright RED sputum possible (bloody)
shape: clumped rods curved +cell wall RNA + DNA intracellular
serology: resistant to gram stain +acid fast (AFB works) slow to grow difficult to see  complement-fixing antibodies test  grow on solid special media (Lowenstein-Jensen media)
virulence factors: mycolic acid = cell wall intracellular survival  inhibits phagosome-lysosome fusion after phagocytosis
antibiotics: -b-lactams +azithromycin +tetracyclins  need to treat with multiple antibiotics(RIPE): +rifampin +isoniazid +pyrazidamide +ethambutol  DOTS = directly observed therapy
mode of transmission: respiratory droplet (aerosols) - for extended periods of time  close contact
immune phenomena: T and B cell activation autoantibody production (agglutinins)  granulomas  can be latent for many years --> reactivation  wasting response
epi. / notes: sporadic overcrowding 2-3 week incubation sickle-cell disease HIV infection  travel from other countries hospital workers

Name: Chlamydophila pneumoniae
Symptoms: 2-10% community acquired pneumonia no fever, patchy persistent cough atherosclerosis
shape: intracellular bacteria only have cell walls reticulate bodies
serology: intracellular bacteria only resistant to gram stain non acid fast
virulence factors: intracellular (evades host defenses)
epi. / notes: overcrowding elderly

Name: Rickettsia
Symptoms: rocky mountain spotted fever  fever, headache, rash red popuoles on skin multiorgan involvement all symptoms present within 2 weeks  hypovolemia hypotension
Sites: natural reservoir: hard ticks  targets: endothelial cells
serology: resistant to gram stain intracellular only  motile like listeria  hyponatremia  dx: PCR, IHC
virulence factors: induces its own phagocytosis  escape from phagosome to enter cytoplasm  host cell actin propulsion like listeria
epi. / notes: (23% fatality if not treated)  MOST COMMON IN THE SOUTHEAST NOT ROCKIES  only summer!!

Name: Ehrlichia chaffeensis
Symptoms: human monocytic ehrlichiosis  maculo-papular rash
serology: -gram but stain poorly intracellular lower WBC lower plt higher LiverFT  blood smear for morula
virulence factors: remain inside phagosome and inhibit fusion and forming morulae
epi. / notes: southeast

Name: Anaplasma phagocytophilum
Symptoms: anaplasmosis  -rash
serology: -gram but stain poorly intracellular lower WBC lower plt higher LFT  blood smear for morula
virulence factors: remain inside phagosome and inhibit fusion and forming morulae
epi. / notes: northeast, same areas a lyme disease

Name: Borrelia burgdorferi
Symptoms: lyme disease early localized: bulls-eye rash, expanding, fever, 3-30 days  early disseminated: 1-4 months, cranial nerve palsy, meningitis, heart block - bradycardia, disseminated rash  late: 3-4 months to years, arthritis, chronic neuro symptoms like radicular pain, encephalopathy, large swelling
Sites: reservoir: white footed mouse, deer for adult stage
serology: IgG and IgM antibody tests (FP; other spirochetes, EBV, SLE, prior lyme infection)  PCR-arthritis  culture and stains notroutinely used
virulence factors: OspA expressed in ticks OspC in human host
mode of transmission: tick bite (blacklegged tick)  nymphs - responsible for most disease
epi. / notes: regions: .northeast .michigan and minnesota  recent hiking  mostly in the summer, but present year round

Name: Bartonella henselae
Symptoms: cat scratch disease fever lymphadenopathy bacterial growth lumps
serology: silver stain -gram but difficult to visualize and grow
antibiotics: usually self-limited  don't usually need to treat
epi. / notes: immunocompromized: bacillary angiomatosis * has a cat, play with cat, scratched or bitten by cat

Name: Leptospirosis
Symptoms: severe systemic organ infections
serology: serum antibodies (1-2 weeks)
mode of transmission: dirt/water dogs  via broken skin or mucosa

Name: Treponema pallidum
Symptoms: syphilis 1e: wart-like lesions, local contagious -self resolves 3-6 wks -painless!! 2e: disseminated rashes -mucous membrane lesions, most cntgus 6-12 wks after inf. -self-resolves -latent: asymptomatic, years 3e: destructive internal lesions and multi-organ system failure -loss of myelin -meningitis, stroke -aortic aneurysms -gummas -irreversible damage
serology: resistant to gram stain dark field microscopy does not grow on regular culture media**  dx: RPR test VDRL test VDRL: non-treponemal antibody 4-8 wks after infection low specificity acute infection!  treponemal test FTA-Abs, MHA-tp sensitive, specific POSITIVE for life
antibiotics: +penicillin G Benzathine one shot ONLY treatment long half life
mode of transmission: sexual contact direct contact  congenital (in utero)
